child.pub-comments: Population: 953,000 in Estonia (1989 census). Population total all countries: 1,018,400. Ethnic population: 963,000 (1989 census). Statutory national language (1992, Constitution, Article 52(1)). Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Standard Estonian is language of education, including universities. Those over 60 and under 20 speak little Russian [rus], especially in rural areas and in southern areas. 75%–80% of the population in the northeast are Russian speakers. Those over 60 know some German [deu]. Most in the north speak Finnish [fin] for common topics. Language Development: Fully developed. Bible: 1739–1995.
child.geography: Estonia. Also in Australia, Canada, Finland, Latvia, Russian Federation, Sweden, United Kingdom, United States.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 5,000 (1998 Federation of Norwegian Kven People). Language use: From 1997 accepted as L2 in Norway. Mostly older adults. Also use Norwegian [nor] or Finnish [fin]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Over 90% in Finnish. Taught in schools 3 hours a week. Newspapers. Educational.
child.geography: Norway: North; Tromso and Finnmark counties, Ruija, Kveeniland; Tromso; Oteren, Skibotn, Storslett, Kvaenangsbotn, Nordreisa, Alta, Borselv, Neiden, Bygoynes, and Vadso.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Intelligible with Standard Estonian [ekk] of the northeast coast. Population: 68 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 73. Language Use: Prefer Russian [rus] in daily communication (2007). Home. Elderly only (2007). All bilingual in Russian [rus]. Language Development: Dictionary.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Saint Petersburg, Kingisepp.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 120 (2010 census). L1 speakers should not be confused with Ingrian Finns, who speak Finnish [fin]. Ethnic population: 820 (1989 census). Language Use: Heavily influenced by Finnish [fin] and Russian [rus] (2007). Few domains. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Baltic, Saint Petersburg, Kingisepp and Lomonosov areas.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 25,600 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Census includes Karelian[krl] and Ludian [lud]. Population total all countries: 30,770. Ethnic population: 65,000. Writing: Latin script. Language Use: erious attempt since 1990 to revive language use. Mainly older adults. A few children learn the language but most if not all become more fluent in Russian [rus] later in life (2007). All also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Poetry. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Ludian [lud] is transitional between Livvi-Karelian and Veps [vep]. Distinct from Karelian and Ludian.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Karelia Republic, Olonetsky, western Pryazhinsky, and southwest Kondopozhsky districts. Also in Finland (Livvi).
child.alt-names: Karelian, Livvi, Livvikovian, Livvikovskij Jazyk, Olonets, Southern Olonetsian
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 15 (1995 V. Zeps). May be one speaker with full competence (Salminen 2007). Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Eastern Livonian has no remaining speakers. Also use Standard Latvian [lvs] or Russian [rus]. Language Development:
child.geography: Latvia: Kurzeme, west of Kolkasrags, 8 coastal villages; Riga area dispersed.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Southeastern dialects called, Karelian, in colloquial Finnish are distinct from true Karelian [krl] (1988 T. Salminen). Finnish is closely related to Karelian [krl] and Livvi [olo]. In the Russian Federation eastern dialects merge gradually into Karelian.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 4,700,000 in Finland (1993). 30,000 speakers of Tornedalen Finnish. Population total all countries: 4,994,490. Writing: Braille script, Latin script. Language use: About 300,000 also use Swedish [swe]. Language Development: Fully developed. Bible: 1642–1991. Statutory national language (2000, Constitution, Article 17(1,2)).
child.geography: Finland. Also in Canada, Estonia, Norway, Russian Federation, Sweden, United States.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 25,600 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Census includes Livvi-Karelian [olo] and Ludian [lud]. Population total all countries: 35,600. Writing: Cyrillic script, no longer in use; Latin script. Language Use: Many children learn the language but most if not all become more fluent in Russian [rus] and largely stop using the language later in life (2007). Many also use Russian [rus], but those over 50 have difficulty understanding it. Some also use Finnish [fin]. Language Development: Primer in Tver Karelian. Dictionary. NT: 2011. Educational.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Karelia Republic; Saint Petersburg; Murmansk Province; Tver Province, mainly Tolmachi area, Maksatikha and Ves’yegonsk. Also in Finland.
child.alt-names: Karelian Proper, Karel’skiy Jazyk, Karely, Severno-Karel’skij, Sobstvenno-Karel’skij-Jazyk
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 25,600 (2010 census). Census includes Karelian [krl] and Livvi-Karelian [olo]. Language Use: Very few children (2007). Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Ludian Society founded in Finland in 1998. Literary language development beginning (Salminen 2007).
child.geography: Russian Federation: Republic of Karelia, central Kondopozhsky and eastern Pryazhinsky districts; Olonetsky district, Mikhaylovskoye region; Arkhangelsk Province, north corner of Onezhsky district.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 30,000 in Sweden (Parkvall 2009). Population total all countries: 60,000. Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Many Saami speak as L2. Mainly older adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Swedish [swe] or Finnish [fin]. Some speakers refer to it as Finnish; Finnish [fin] not totally intelligible to speakers, especially abstract and complex discourse.. Influences from Swedish [swe]. Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–30%. Magazines. Grammar. Bible portions: 1993–1995. Statutory provincial language in administrative area municipalities: Gällivare, Haparanda, Kiruna, Pajala, Övertoneå (2009, NMNML Act No. 724, Art, 6).
child.geography: Sweden: Northeast, Norrbotten County, Gällivare, Kiruna, Pajala, Övertorneå, and Haparanda municipalities. Also in Finland.
child.alt-names: Meänkieli, North Finnish, Torne Valley Finnish, Tornedalsfinska
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Seto is linguisticaly very close to Eastern Võro but many Setos consider Seto an independent language. There are about 5,000 Seto speakers.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 60,000 (2009 S. Iva). Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Rapid shift to Standard Estonian [ekk]. Home, workplace. Few children; most are elderly speakers living in rural areas. Language Development: Promotion and revival of Võro, which includes teachers, politicians, poets, geographers, and administrators, attempting to increase the usage. Taught in primary schools. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.
child.geography: Estonia: South-East Estonia - Võru and Põlva counties, parts of Valga and Tartu counties (about 10% of Estonia’s territory).
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Pejorative names exist: “Chudy”, “Chuhari”, “Chukhari”. Population: 3,610 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 8,240. Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Used by few children. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literary language based on central dialect. Taught in some primary schools, but not compulsory. Poetry. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Among Russian speakers, Saint Petersburg and Vologda Province boundary; Karelian Republic.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Forest and Tundra Enets [enh] barely mutually intelligible. Transitional between Nenets [yrk] and Nganasan [nio]. Formerly officially considered part of Nenets. Population: 40 (2010 census). Census includes Tundra Enets [enh]. Ethnic population: 200 with Tundra Enets (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Few domains. Mainly older adults. Neutral attitudes. All bilingual or trilingual. Language Development: Taught in primary schools in Potapovo. Dictionary. Grammar.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Potapovo, Dudinka, and other Taimyr settlements. Most are in Potapovo.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Forest and Tundra Enets [enh] barely mutually intelligible. Transitional between Nenets [yrk] and Nganasan [nio]. Formerly officially considered part of Nenets. Population: 40 (2010 census). 6 in Vorontsovo, 3 in Karepovsk (2005 O. Khanina and A. Shluinsky). Ethnic population: 200 together with Forest Enets (2002 census). Language Use: Under 10% of ethnic group speaks Enets. Few domains. Mainly older adults. Neutral attitudes. Bilingual in Russian [rus]. Some also use Nganasan [nio] (Salminen 2007). Language Development: Grammar.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Vorontsovo and Karepovsk settlements; some nomads near Tukhard.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 130 (2010 census). A group of about 100 lead a semi-nomadic life in Dudypta river region near Ust’-Avam (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 830. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: There are very few child speakers except in the semi-nomadic group, whose members use it more actively. Outside this group, only those 40 and older are fully fluent (2007). Limited use in the home. Mainly adults. Neutral to mildly positive attitudes. Ethnic pride expressed; status enhanced by knowledge of Nganasan. Also use Russian [rus] or Dolgan [dlg]. Middle-aged and younger are fully bilingual in Russian (Salminen 2007). Language Development: Taught in primary schools as L2 to Avam-Nganasan children. Dictionary. Grammar.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Siberia, Taimyr peninsula, Krasnoyarsk District, Duinka region, Ust-Avam and Volochanka villages; Khatang region, Novaya village. Northernmost people in Russia, near Yakut [sah], Dolgan [dlg], Nenets [yrk], and (Tundra) Enets [enh] language areas.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 21,900 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 41,300 including both Forest Nenets and Tundra Nenets. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: In Siberia most young people are still fluent in the language. On the European side, very few children learn it; young people tend to prefer Russian [rus] and most speakers are middle-aged or older (Salminen 2007). A few to half of children speak Nenets. Positive attitudes. In Siberia, many school-age children also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Most attended school and read Russian. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2004–2010.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Northwest Siberia, north Dvina river mouth tundra area to Yenisei river delta; scattered in Kola peninsula, Nenets and Yamalia autonomous regions; Krasnoyarsk District.
child.alt-names: Nenec, Nenetsy, Nentse, Yurak, Yurak Samoyed
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Sayan mountains, Abalakovo village.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Dialect continuum with difficult or impossible intelligibility between extremes. Southern speakers separated geographically from others. Northern Selkup literature not usable by Southern and Central.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Dialect continuum with difficult or impossible intelligibility between extremes. Southern speakers separated geographically from others. Northern Selkup literature not usable by Southern and Central.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Dialect continuum with difficult or impossible intelligibility between extremes. Southern speakers separated geographically from others. Northern Selkup literature not usable by Southern and Central.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Dialect continuum with difficult or impossible intelligibility between extremes. Southern speakers separated geographically from others. Northern Selkup literature not usable by Southern and Central.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,020 (2010 census). Central Selkup: 200 speakers, Northern Selkup: 1,000 to 1,500 speakers, Southern Selkup: less than 100 speakers (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 4,250. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: In Ratta and Purovskaya Tolka almost everybody knows Selkup, including children and other ethnicities. Northern dialect spoken by 90% of people, but not mastered by young adults and children. Southern dialect spoken by 30%; 10–15 adults, all over 70, speak fluently. Most children are monolingual Russian [rus] speakers (2007). Positive attitudes among Northern Selkups, neutral attitudes among Central and Southern Selkups. Russian [rus] also used for most key domains, except perhaps family. Language Development: Northern dialect taught in schools through fourth grade. Grammar.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Tomsk Province; Yamalia and Nenetsia autonomous regions, Krasnoyarsk District. Northern dialect: Krasnoselkup region, Ratta, Krasnoselkupskaya Tolka, and Krasnoselkup villages; Purovsk region, Tolka Purovskaya village; Krasnoyarsk District, Farkovo; Turukhan river basin; Baikha. Southern dialect: north Tomsk Province area villages.
child.alt-names: Central Selkups, Chumyl’ Khumyt, Northern Selkups, Ostyak Samoyed, Shöl Khumyt, Shösh Gulla, Syusugulla
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: 80% with Komi-Zyrian [kpv] and Udmurt [udm]. Population: 63,100 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 125,000. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script, used during the 1930s and 1940s. Old Permic script, no longer in use. Some literature available. Ancient literary and cultural traditions. More densely populated and mixed, higher education, and more assimilated to national culture than Komi-Zyria. Language Use: In the Komi-Permyak area there are villages where people speak hardly any other language except Komi-Permyak. Many children learn the language, but only in rural areas do they continue to use it as adults. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Bible portions: 1866–2009.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Komi-Permyak National Region, west of central Ural mountains, south of Komi-Zyrian.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Lexical similarity: 80% with Komi-Permyak [koi] and Udmurt [udm]. Population: 156,000 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 293,000. Wrtiting: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Komi used in Institute for Language and Literature of the Komi branch of the Academy of Science. Many children learn the language but many stop using it later in life (2007). Also use Nenets [yrk] or Russian [rus]. Language Development: Bible: 1990.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Komi Republic, near the Arctic Ocean. South of Yurak [yrk], west of Vogul (Mansi) [mns] language areas.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 324,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 339,800. Ethnic population: 637,000, plus 3,100 Besermyan speakers. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin Script. Language Use: The Besermyan are Udmurt-speaking Tatar. Many children learn the language but only those living in remote rural areas continue to use it actively (2007). Also use Russian [rus].
child.geography: Russian Federation: Near Ural Mountains, Udmurtia Republic, 1,000 km northeast of Moscow, bounded by Kama and Cheptsa rivers. Also in Kazakhstan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 2,000 speakers of Eastern Khanty
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 9,580 (2010 census). Mostly speakers of Northern Khanty, 2,000 speakers of Eastern Khanty and probably no speakers left in Southern Khanty (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 28,700. Intelligibility difficult between geographically distant dialects. 3 dialect groups; ‘Vach’, archaic. Dialect used in writing rejected by many speakers. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: 20%–60% of the ethnic group speaks Khanty. In Eastern Khanty, some child speakers but many shift to Russian [rus] at school age. Northern Khanty is still used in the home but boarding school system often forces a shift to Russian among younger generations. In Southern Khanty, transmission of the language to children stopped long ago. Assimilated to Siberian Tatar [tat] and Russian. Few domains. Used by few children. Positive attitudes. Some also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Russian used in schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1868–2007.
child.geography: Russia: Central Russia: Khantia-Mansia Autonomous Region; east past the Mansi [mns] language area, along Ob river.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Most similar to the Uralic language Vogul (Mansi [mns]) in Siberia. Speakers of standard Hungarian have difficulty understanding the Oberwart dialect spoken in Austria, and considerable difficulty understanding the Moldavian Csángó dialect spoken in Rumania. Writing: Braille script. Latin script, primary usage. Population: 9,550,000 in Hungary (2001 census). 60,000–70,000 in Romania and Moldova speak Csango. Population total all countries: 12,319,330. De facto national language. Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1590–1991.
child.geography: Hungary: Widespread. Also in Australia, Austria, Canada, Croatia, Czech Republic, Israel, Romania, Russian Federation, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, Ukraine, United States.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: A pejorative name exists: “Lapp”. Population: 300 in Sweden (Krauss 1992). Population total all countries: 600. Ethnic population: 600. Writing: Latin script. Language use: Used by few children. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Bible portions. Statutory provincial language in administrative area municipalities located in at least part of the following counties: Dalarna, Jämtland, Norrbotten, Västerbotten (2009, NMNML Act No. 724, Article 6).
child.geography: Sweden: Lapland; Dalarna, Jämtland, and Härjedalen. Also in Norway.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: A pejorative name exists: “Lapp”. Population: 20 in Sweden (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 2,000 (1995 M. Krauss). Language Use: Increased literary activity. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%.
child.geography: Sweden: Lapland, Arjeplog and Arvidsjaur, along Pite river. Also in Norway.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Two-thirds of all Saami speak Ruija dialect.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Pejorative names exist: “Lapp”, “Northern Lappish”, “Norwegian Lapp”. Population: Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script, primary usage. Language Use: In central Finnmark Province, where North Saami has an official status, many children learn the language and are likely to continue to use it in adulthood (2007). All ages. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught in primary schools. New media. Bible: 1895. Statutory provincial language in Sami Administrative District (1987, Sami Act, No. 12, Article 3).
child.geography: Norway: Finnmark, Troms provinces; Nordland province, Ofoten. Also in Finland, Sweden.
child.alt-names: Lapp, Northern Lappish, Northern Saami, Norwegian Lapp, Saami, Same, Samic, Davvin, Northern Lapp, Saame, Norwegian Saami
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: A pejorative name exists: “Lapp”. Population: 1,500 in Sweden (Krauss 1992). 1,000–2,000 speakers in Norway and Sweden (Salminen 2007). Population total all countries: 2,000. Ethnic population: 6,000. Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Language use has recently been activated to some extent. Younger speakers may nevertheless prefer Swedish [swe] (2007). Used by few children. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 1903–2003. Statutory provincial language in administrative area municipalities located in at least part of the following counties: Dalarna, Jämtland, Norrbotten, Västerbotten (2009, NMNML Act No. 724, Article 6).
child.geography: Sweden: Lapland, Gällivare and Jokkmokk, along Lule river. Also in Norway.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Pejorative names exist: “Kildin Lappish”, “Lapp”. Writing: Cyrillic script. Population: 350 (2010 census). Census includes Skolt Saami [sms] and Ter Saami [sjt]. Ethnic population: 2,000 including all Saami (2002 census). 1,900 Saami in the Russian Federation (1995 M. Krauss). Language Use: Mostly middle-aged or older. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Local literacy effort.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Kola peninsula.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Pejorative names exist: “Finnish Lapp”, “Inari Lappish”, “Lapp”. Writing: Latin script. Population: 300 (2001 census). 4,700 all Saami in Finland (1995). Ethnic population: 700 (1995 M. Krauss). Language Use: Few children used to learn it before the founding of the first Inari Saami language nest in 1997. Now a substantial portion of youth are growing as functional bilinguals (2007). Also use Finnish [fin]. Schooling is in Finnish. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Bible portions: 1903–1980. Statutory provincial language in Sodankyla in Lapland, 3 municipalities elsewhere (2003, Sami Language Act No. 1086).
child.geography: Finland: Lapland, above 68.00 N latitude, between Lake Inari and Norway border, mostly Utsjoki border town area.
child.alt-names: Anar, Finnish Lapp, Inari Lappish, Lapp, Saam, Saame, Sámi, Samic
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Pejorative names exist: “Lapp”, “Ter Lappish”. Population: 350 (2010 census). Census includes Kildin Saami [sjd] and Skolt Saami [sms]. 6 elderly speakers in the early 1990s (Salminen 2007). Language Use: Mainly older adults. Also use Russian [rus].
child.geography: Russian Federation: Kola peninsula.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: A pejorative name exists: “Lapp”. Population: 300 in Finland (Salminen 2007). Population total all countries: 650. Ethnic population: 500 in Finland (1995 M. Krauss). Writing: Latin script. Language Use: Very few children learn the language (2007). Mainly older adults. Also use Finnish [fin]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1878–1988. Statutory language of provincial identity in Sodankyla in Lapland, 3 municipalities elsewhere (2003, Sami Language Act No. 1086).
child.geography: Finland: Lapland, Inari county, Sevettijärvi region. Also in Russian Federation. Moved to Finland from Russia during World War II.
child.alt-names: Kolta, Koltta, Lapp, Lopar, Russian Lapp, Saame, Same, Skolt Lappish
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Most similar to Skolt Saami [sms]. Population: No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: 100 (1995 M. Krauss). Language Use: Some descendants of Akkala Saami speak Kildin Saami [sjd] but most have shifted to Russian [rus] (2007).
child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwest Kola peninsula.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: A pejorative name exists: “Lapp”. Population: 20 (2000 T. Salminen). No speakers in Norway (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 1,000 (1995 M. Krauss). Language Use: Few remaining speakers. Elderly only (2007). Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Bible: 1811.
child.geography: Sweden: Lycksele, Malå, Tärna, and Sorsele, along Ume river.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.alt-names: Northern Mansi, Ob', Sos'va, Sosyvin, Sygva, Upper Lozyvin
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.alt-names: Lower Lozyvin, Middle Lozyvin, Pelym, Vagily, Western Mansi
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 940 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 11,400. Mostly Northern Vogul speakers; probably only a handful of elderly speakers of Eastern Vogul; Western Vogul is probably extinct; Southern Vogul was extinct before 1950 (Salminen 2007). Most similar to Hungarian [hun]. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Mansi spoken by 50% or less of the ethnic group; most shifted to Russian [rus]. Few domains. Few to half of the children learn Mansi. Eastern Mansi is used only by older adults. Neutral to very positive attitudes. Some also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Russian [rus] used in schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1868–2007.
child.geography: Russia: Central Russia: Western Siberia, Komi-Zyrian [kpv] language area to the west of the Urals; between Ural and Ob rivers.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 388,000 (2010 census). Census includes Meadow Mari [mhr]. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language use: Includes a few child speakers. Also use Russian [rus] or Meadow Mari [mhr].
child.geography: Russian Federation: Mari El Republic, south of the Volga, Gornomariysky district; Bashkortostan Republic.
child.alt-names: Cheremis, Gorno-Mariy, High Mari, Mari-Hills, Western Mari
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 388,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Census includes Hill Mari [mrj]. Population total all countries: 397,090. Ethnic population: 604,300. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script. Language use: Many children learn the language but only those in remote rural areas continue to use it actively. In eastern diaspora areas in Bashkortostan practically all children learn the language (2007). Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Newspapers. Radio programs.
child.geography: Russian Federation: Mari El Republic, east of the Volga, Bashkir, and Tatar; Udmurtia Republic; Perm District; Kirov Province. Also in Kazakhstan (Eastern Mari).
child.alt-names: Cheremis, Eastern Mari, Low Mari, Lugovo Mari, Mari, Mari-Woods
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 431,700 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Census includes Moksha [mdf]. Population total all countries: 514,330. Ethnic population: 843,350 Mordvin in Russia. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Many children learn the language but most of them use it only with elderly relatives. Vitality higher in Eastern diaspora areas than in the Republic (2007). Quite acculturated to national culture and Russian [rus].
child.geography: Russian Federation: North and east Mordovia Republic; Nizhny Novgorod, Ulynovsk, Penza, Samara provinces; Orenburg Province, Buguruslan; Chuvashia, Tartastan, and Bashkortostan republics. Also in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Estonia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 432,000 (2010 census). Census includes Erzya [myv]. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: The Tengushen are Erzya ethnically, but speak Moksha. Many children learn the language but usually only use it with elderly relatives (2007). Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Bible portions: 1879-2009.
child.geography: Russian Federation: West Mordovia Republic; Ryazan and Penza provinces; Tatarstan Republic, Orenburg Province, scattered.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

root.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
